article.description: Moochie Norris made a 3-pointer from the corner at the buzzer to lift the Houston Rockets over the Knicks 88-86 Tuesday night, New York's third straight loss.
article.headline: Norris 3 sends Knicks to third straight loss
article.linkText: Norris buzzer-beater lifts Rockets over Knicks
article.story:
HOUSTON (AP) -- Moochie Norris is making a habit of hitting big shots at the end of games. The reserve guard came through again Tuesday night, making a 3-pointer from the corner at the buzzer to lift the Houston Rockets over the Knicks 88-86, New York's third straight loss. "The dude is amazing," teammate Cuttino Mobley said. "It seems like he always hits those shots. After this one, I looked at him and just said you are blessed man." It was the fourth buzzer-beater of Norris' career. He hit a 3-pointer to beat Phoenix earlier this season and hit similar shots to defeat Indiana and Golden State in 2000-01. "It seems whenever it comes down to crunch time, Steve (Francis) or Cuttino get the ball and I always walk up to them and say, 'If my man leaves me, look for me in the corner,' " Norris said. "It feels great being in those situations. It's something you dream about." Norris, who had 13 points, was called for an offensive foul with 13 seconds to play. That led to Allan Houston's basket, which gave the Knicks an 86-85 lead with 7 seconds left. The Rockets worked the inbounds pass to Francis, but he got bottled up near the basket and passed to Norris, who was alone in the corner. After the ball went through the net, Norris went over and jumped on the scorer's table. "The play was designed for me to drive left, but they took that away from me immediately," Francis said. "All I could see was a bunch of blue jerseys around me. But then I saw something blazing in the corner and it looked like he wanted the ball. I knew I had to hit him or I'd hear about it later. "This just seems to keep happening. Every time we're down, we know we can count on Moochie to knock the shot down." Coach Rudy Tomjanovich anticipated Francis getting doubled when the Rockets set up the last play during a time out. "I told Steve that when he gets in there that they would collapse on him, and he made the great decision to hit Moochie in the corner," Tomjanovich said. "We've got three penetrators and guys who can all shoot the ball." New York has lost five of its last six games and dropped to 4-11 since Don Chaney replaced Jeff Van Gundy as coach. "We've lost a lot that way," Chaney said. "When Allen hit that shot, I thought the tide had changed. It was like the nail in the coffin. It was good execution. If you talk about luck and bad luck, we've had it. I thought our guys fought very hard tonight, especially on back-to-back nights. We fought hard enough to win." Latrell Sprewell, who was guarding Francis, was upset that Charlie Ward left Norris to help on Francis. "I would have liked to have stayed totally in front of (Francis)," Sprewell said. "He went behind his back. He's a good player. I think Charlie has to stay (on Norris). That's the bottom line." Kenny Thomas scored 24 points, and Francis 19 for the Rockets. Houston led the Knicks with 28 points, and Mark Jackson scored 14. But Sprewell, who came into the game as the Knicks' leading scorer with a 20.1-point average, shot just 4-for-15 from the floor and scored eight. Thomas scored 14 points in the first quarter, when the Rockets led by as many as seven before taking a 26-21 edge into the second period. The Rockets stretched the lead to as many as nine points as Eddie Griffin scored six points and blocked three shots in the second quarter. Jackson hit a 22-foot jumper at the buzzer to close Houston's lead to 42-36 at halftime. The Knicks made an early 7-2 run in the third quarter to pull within 46-45. But Knicks forward Kurt Thomas was ejected after getting two consecutive technicals for arguing a call with 7:00 left in the third and the Rockets quickly opened the lead back up to 53-47. New York got 11 points from Houston in the quarter to keep it close and the Rockets had to settle for a 68-64 lead after three. The Knicks quickly erased that advantage by scoring the first seven points of the fourth quarter. It was the beginning of a 10-2 run that gave New York a 74-70 lead with 8:41 to play. The Rockets scored four quick points to tie it again and the lead went back and forth after that. Mobley's follow shot with 1:29 gave Houston an 85-84 lead.

Game notes
Knicks C Travis Knight left the game in the first quarter with a knee injury. He will have an MRI exam Wednesday to determine the extent of the injury. ... The Knicks have lost nine of their last 10 games in Houston. ... The Knicks, who lost to the Spurs on Monday night, are 3-5 in the first games of back-to-backs this season and 2-6 in the second games. ... The Rockets are 10-7 in games Francis has played and 1-16 in games without him this season.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
